content.description: Bring your boulderer buddies here to do this one. When it's so short, it can't be easy.
content.location: This is the second to last of the three bolt lines on the short wall before you reach the main cave with Toomsuba.

content.description: Use sloping edges to climb through the small roofs.
Welcome to the area warmup. Vogue begins in a crack (that doesn't require crack climbing technique) before moving onto a nice face just left of the arete.
content.location: This is the first route you encounter when entering the Toomsuba area.

content.description: 4th class to left of wet streak. Ease out slopers to steep arete. Expect a fight (hence the name). Worth the inconvenient start once you've done the other classics in the area. You could also aid up the start of Big Brother to gain the big ledge that this route starts on, but both ways are a pain in the ass. In my own opinion, you have to experience this route if you consider yourself a local in the canyon.
content.protection: 4 bolts and anchors. *I suggest extending the fist two draws to reduce drag*
content.location: Far left end of Toomsuba. Walk around the left side corner of the Take/Tension wall and look for the obvious, overhanging arete.

content.description: Stick clip the first bolt. Begin low in the cave and boulder your way out on slopers until you can turn the lip. Cruise up to an enormous jug where you can get it all back before the face climbing up higher. Classic.
content.location: This route begins in the back of a small cave and climbs out its right edge on slopers.

content.description: "Pull of the deck with some quick juice to good holds and an eventual ledge. Summon the power for crux moves to gain stance above roof." -Little River Canyon Guide Book, Adam Henry
content.location: Two routes to the right of Slo-lo.

content.description: Thuggy sloper jugs to hard lip turn. Get it back on the flexing jug crimp, and sprint through perfect stone after tiered roof. Shares anchors with Skin Changer.
content.location: Right of Take

content.description: Steep jug pulling down low leads into technical face climbing above. If it wasn't for the chossy band of rock in the middle of this climb, it would be four stars because the movement is excellent.
content.location: To the right of hang me on the far end of Toomsumba.

content.description: Start on the first few feet of Toomsuba. As soon as you reach the ceiling, grab and undercling and punch left through the roof on decent edges past a couple bolts and a bouldery toss onto the steep face above. Rest away the pump for some small holds guarding the chains.
content.protection: Stick clip. 4 bolts, consider clipping #2 real short if you have a light belayer
content.location: Shares start rocks and first couple moves with Toomsuba.

content.description: This climb starts on steep overhanging jugs, but don't let that fool you, the crux is getting past the vertical crack at the top.
content.location: 3 routes to the left of Guillotine Crack, the route with the giant scary flake feature.

content.description: Start on pedestal, dyno to jugs. Climb through some business while turning lip, and enjoy thought provoking face climbing to the top.
content.location: Right of Tension

content.description: Scramble up to ledge then climb a couple of easy moves to bizarre crux.
content.protection: 6 bolts and anchor. *anchor is very rusty as of 09/20/2018 so I just climbed up to the anchor, touched it, then down-climbed to the last bolt and lowered from a biner on the last bolt.
content.location: One route right of Flex.

content.description:
One of the steepest in the canyon, but this is no fitness route! Begin by clipping the first permadraw of Majosha and then break right. Put long slings on the next two bolts, which are all jugs and occasionally seep. Rest up at the base of the roof, and then begin the v9ish boulder problem crux, with the moves at the lip being the hardest. Crimp strength and a strong core will go a long way. 

 After the boulder problem, get a decent rest in a sort of corner. Clip this bolt and the next with long slings. Traverse left through some crumbly rock, and then begin a possible heartbreaker sequence at the last bolt. The finish to this route is still 5.12 and almost always wet...

 One thing to note - it is very easy (and worth it) to work this route just through the crux with 5 draws.
content.location: Base of the big steep prow at Toomsuba. Shares start with Majosha, which has chain draws.

content.description: Climb past a high first bolt to an undercling.  Power to a good hold and juggy finish.
content.protection: Bolts to bolted anchor. Stick Clip.
content.location: Fourth line right of Toomsuba

content.description: Traverse out seam of roof, pull lip, and slab it to the top.
content.location: Right of Guillotine Crack

content.description: Classic Doug Reed route. Surmount a small ledge at the base and fire a thin technical pull. Traverse towards the right a bit underneath the roof and make sequential moves to gain access to a sloping jug.    Huck a big move and trend left until you reach the finale consisting of a overhangin hand crack looming above the canyon.   Summon your inner trad skills to pull the small roof and thrutch your way to the finishing ledge to clip the chains.
content.location: To the left of "prodigal"   Look for the obvious large roof route with fixed chains.

content.description: Climb short mini roof. Pull tricky move at lip to anchors.
content.location: Four routes left of Flex.

content.description: Moderate climbing leads to ledge. Move right along sloping shelf to small arete feature. Find hidden crimps and scramble to the anchors.
content.location: One route right of Slo-lo.

content.description: Climb up to the corner and move left on jugs to the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts and bolted anchors w/ chains and biners

content.description:
"An adventure climb sprinkled with a few tricky boulder problems. Climb steep jugs to left facing corner. Trad your way through funky moves to good stance at base of slab. Figure out correct use of slopers, gastons, and crimps to gain big break. Long moves on decent holds lead to eventual jug haul and anchors. A must do." -Little River Canyon Guide Book, Adam Henry

 *Canyon Man Route*
content.location: Far left end of Toomsuba. Last route on the left side of the main Take/Tension wall.

content.description: Short and powerful on great stone. Crux involves a long thrutch on small but positive edges.
content.location: Striking line with a fixed chain at the 4th bolt.

content.description: Fight your way up the eponymous boulder problem involving at least one hand jam and a not insignificant amount of struggle to get established on top of the large side pull flake, and win as your reward the rest of the route which is a fun, steep jug haul with interesting features and movement.
content.location: Head climber's left along the wall past Majosha. Climb starts on top of a boulder. Starts on jugs up to the base of the roof where there's a left trending hand crack around the side of a large lieback side pull.

content.description: Big moves to a tough crux to a small edge. Keep fighting to the anchors!
Climb jugs for 20 feet to business on crimps.
content.location: One route left of Cheesecake.

content.description: Sloping jugs to a pinch block and a far left reach.
One of the few 9s in the canyon. Fun romp on big holds to a mantle at the top.
content.location: This is the first route you come to when you get to Toomsuba. On the far right of the wall.

content.description: Awkward traverse to big slot to steep climbing on smaller edges. Hero finish move. Rock is blank  ear the first bolt so start as ADR to the right and traverse in.
content.location: Just right of large crack of Toomsuba.

content.description: Move through slopey jugs and crimps to brief crux at first bolt. Follow trail of sidepulls and slopey ledges to second bolt, leading to a variety of moves on (mostly) jugs to the anchors.
content.location: Two routes to the right of Toomsuba.

content.description: Toomsuba is a continuation of the Tourist Wall. It faces due south and receives full sun, so it is a fantastic winter destination. Not a dog friendly crag due to the down-climb/scramble. Stays dry in light rain, but not the best spot for a downpour.
